node.title: A Robot Wrote This Book Review
node.description: In “The Age of AI,” Henry Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher explore how far artificial intelligence has come.
node.content: ["THE AGE OF AIAnd Our Human FutureBy Henry A. Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher", "One of the great promises of technology is that it can do the work that humans find too boring or arduous.", "In the 19th and 20th centuries, factory machines relieved us of repetitive manual labor and backbreaking farm work. In this century, artificial intelligence has taken care of a few more tasks \u2014 curating Spotify playlists, selecting the next YouTube video, vacuuming the floor and so on \u2014 but many more mind-numbing activities remain ripe for the picking. The experts promise us that someday, all of our least favorite chores \u2014 including complex cognitive ones, like interviewing job candidates or managing global supply chains \u2014 will be outsourced to machines.", "But that day has not yet arrived. Or has it?", "After finishing \u201cThe Age of AI,\u201d a new book about artificial intelligence by Henry A. Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher, I found myself unmoved by the prospect of reviewing it. I\u2019ve read dozens of books about A.I., and while the conceit of this one was intriguing \u2014 bringing together a 98-year-old diplomat, a former Google chief executive and an M.I.T. professor \u2014 the book itself was a fairly forgettable entry in the genre.", "Then I got a bright idea. What if I could have an A.I. finish this review, and save myself the trouble?", "So I fired up Sudowrite, an A.I. writing program I\u2019ve been experimenting with recently. The app uses GPT-3, the cutting-edge A.I. system developed by the San Francisco-based OpenAI, which acts as a kind of turbocharged version of Gmail\u2019s autocomplete feature. Provide a snippet of text, and GPT-3 will try to complete it, using everything it has learned from ingesting billions of examples of other people\u2019s writing. It does this with the help of a supercomputer containing some 285,000 processors, and a multilayered neural network that ranks among the world\u2019s most powerful A.I. engines. The authors of \u201cThe Age of AI\u201d call GPT-3 one of several promising technologies that are producing a \u201crevolution in human affairs.\u201d", "I pasted the first several paragraphs of this review into Sudowrite, and asked the A.I. to finish. Here\u2019s what it wrote:", "Henry Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher\u2019s \u201cThe Age of AI\u201d is a bold new book on artificial intelligence that will become the go-to guide for anyone who wants to understand this transformative technology.", "The authors have examined the full range of AI technologies \u2014 from computer vision systems to natural language processing \u2014 and written about them in a way that will appeal to both experts and laypeople.", "One of the most inspiring aspects of this book is its scope. The authors delve deeply into the potential of AI in all areas of human enterprise. They describe the impact of AI on health care, economics, geopolitics, law, urban development, governance, journalism, the military and even the life sciences.", "Kissinger, Schmidt and Huttenlocher are not afraid to explore the darkest side of AI, either. They are clear-eyed about the ways that AI could enable dictators to monitor their citizens and manipulate information to incite people to commit violence.", "Although AI is already making our lives better in many ways, Kissinger, Schmidt and Huttenlocher caution that it will take us as a species many years to create a system as powerful as we deserve. They wisely suggest that we not lose sight of the values we want to instill in this new machine intelligence.", "Thank you, GPT-3! Now, a few notes:", "First, the A.I. wasn\u2019t an unqualified success. It took Sudowrite a few tries. On the first attempt, it spit out a series of run-on sentences that hinted that GPT-3 had gotten stuck in some kind of odd, recursive loop. (It began: \u201cThe book which you are reading at the moment is a book on a nook, which is a book on a book, which is a book on a subject, which is a subject on a subject, which is a subject on a subject.\u201d) A few tries later, it seemed to give up on the task of book reviewing altogether, and started merely listing the names of tech companies. (\u201cGoogle, Facebook, Apple, Amazon, IBM, Microsoft, Baidu, Tencent, Tesla, Uber, Airbnb, Twitter, Snap, Alibaba, WeChat, Slack.\u201d)", "But it warmed up quickly, and within a few minutes, the A.I. was coming up with impressively cogent paragraphs of analysis \u2014 some, frankly, better than what I could have generated on my own.", "This speaks to one of the recurring themes of \u201cThe Age of AI,\u201d which is that although today\u2019s A.I. systems can be clunky and erratic at times, they are getting better fast, and will soon match or surpass human proficiency in a number of important tasks, solving problems in ways no human would have thought to solve them. At that point, the authors write, A.I. will \u201ctransform all realms of human experience.\u201d", "Second, while GPT-3 was correct about the scope of \u201cThe Age of AI\u201d \u2014 with chapters on everything from social media algorithms to autonomous weapons \u2014 it failed to note that all of that broadness comes at a cost. The book feels cursory and shallow in places, and many of its recommendations are puzzlingly vague.", "In a chapter on the geopolitical risks posed by A.I., the authors conclude that \u201cthe nations of the world must make urgent decisions regarding what is compatible with concepts of inherent human dignity and moral agency.\u201d (OK, we\u2019ll get right on that!) A brief section about TikTok \u2014 an app used by more than a billion people worldwide, whose ownership by a Chinese company raises legitimately fascinating questions about national sovereignty and free speech \u2014 ends with the throwaway observation that \u201cmore complex geopolitical and regulatory riddles await us in the near future.\u201d And when the authors do make specific recommendations \u2014 such as a proposal to restrict the use of A.I. in developing biological weapons \u2014 they fail to elaborate on how such an outcome might be achieved, or who might stand in its way.", "Finally, GPT-3 didn\u2019t address the biggest question about the book, which is why it exists at all. Kissinger, who was 66 years old when the World Wide Web was invented, is not a full-time A.I. practitioner, nor a particularly savvy parser of tech hype. (His last newsworthy foray into the tech world was when he sat on the board of Theranos, the doomed blood-testing start-up.) Schmidt, who spent a decade running Google, is these days preoccupied with trying to scare up military contracts for big tech companies. And while Huttenlocher, the dean of M.I.T.\u2019s Schwarzman College of Computing, may be a bona fide subject matter expert, it\u2019s not clear how much of the book he actually wrote.", "That said, the book does get some things right. The authors do a commendable job of avoiding what I call \u201cA.I. fatalism\u201d \u2014 the belief, sadly common in tech circles, that A.I. is part of an inevitable future whose course we are powerless to change. Instead, they write that \u201chumans still control\u201d A.I., and have the opportunity to \u201cshape it with our values.\u201d They also point out, correctly, that while many people worry about killer robots who achieve human-level sentience and mow us all down with Uzis, a much bigger near-term danger lurks in the innocuous-seeming A.I.s we all use every day, from the feed-ranking algorithms of social media apps to the automated dispatch systems that power Uber and Lyft.", "\u201cWithout significant fanfare \u2014 or even visibility \u2014 we are integrating nonhuman intelligence into the basic fabric of human activity,\u201d they write.", "Still, while it could be a useful summary of A.I. for those just starting to learn about the topic, \u201cThe Age of AI\u201d does not advance the ball much. It\u2019s a shame, given how much access the authors presumably had to a who\u2019s who of the A.I. elite. And it makes me wish that\u2026", "Actually, you know what? It\u2019s sunny outside, my dogs need a walk, and I don\u2019t really feel like finishing this review. Take it away, GPT-3.", "\u2026It makes me wish that someone out there would crank out a comprehensive survey text on AI, one that\u2019s laser-focused on the technical issues, written by industry mavens who are actually doing this stuff day in and day out, and is written in an engaging, clear, plain-spoken style.", "I couldn\u2019t have said it better myself."]
